conference_notes:
• Mr Leonard pointed out that meaningful engagement of Indigenous Nations in ocean planning they found that open data policies must include Indigenous nation consultation by institutions/organizations/agencies on research priorities, funding, and administration; active approval by Indigenous communities of research taking place on Indigenous lands/waters;alternative data sharing agreements that acknowledge Indigenous sovereignty over data and allow for security protocols; and training for scientific review panels responsible for granting funding to value Traditional Knowledge.
  • Ms Hunter and Violeta Dominguez exposed how they developed an approach to working with Arizona’s tribal communities in ways that honor their culture and their tribal sovereignty, in particular around research and evaluation efforts
  • Mr Cunningam explained how data can bring knowledge from misunderstandings and false thoughts with the example of the belief of the “abuse of alcohol”. Rates proved Native Americans compared to whites had lower or comparable rates across the range of alcohol measures examined.
  • Mr Hwang explains that by opening up the high-quality data for Indigenous, pollutant emissions, national map, and water quality, they proposed the "collective" way to collaborate with global academia, government, and industry, to work on the impacts of climate change for global society and especially for Indigenous people.
name: Openness and National Statistical Offices: A Review of Available Tools and Methods
info:
This session focused on the broader context for interactions among the National Statistical Offices (NSO) and Open Data communities. 

Questions to answer were:

- How can open data help with addressing some of the SDG data challenges?
- Where can NSOs and their partners get big returns from their investment in data, even in 2016? 
- Are there places for quick actions or low-hanging fruit? 
- What are the experiences of NSOs actively involved in this work? 
- What are the key tools and services partner agencies are offering to support open data in NSOs?
